proposals.reasoning: This aligns with the emerging consensus while keeping the initial team low-drama and information-rich. Putting myself (Diana) with Alice gives us a clean baseline if it succeeds and highly focused suspicion if it fails, without immediately entangling Bob or Eve—both of whom are harder to read early and can be better evaluated from how they vote and react to this first mission. Charlie also preferred this over pairing Alice with Bob, which helps maintain broader trust and avoids concentrating too much early influence in a single duo.

votes.comment: Solid consensus start; keeps both Bob and Eve off for clearer early voting info without looking like a power duo.
It’s the consensus low-drama start, and rejecting a reasonable Alice+Diana opener would look needlessly suspicious.
This matches the low-drama M1 I already advocated (Alice + Diana), and a clean first mission with both evils off it is fine for information later.
I’m on the team and the composition matches the table’s consensus for a low-risk, high-info Mission 1.
Acceptable low-drama M1; I’m okay taking the info and revisiting hard if it comes back dirty.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d lean toward a simple, low-drama team like me with either Diana or Eve, and let Bob/Charlie’s reactions and voting patterns give us more to work with before we throw them straight onto a quest.

I’m fine starting simple, but I actually like something like Alice + me here so we spread early info a bit and don’t park both “trusted” spots in the same social circle. If that feels too weird, I’d rather see Alice + Diana than Alice + Eve, just because Eve tends to fly under the radar when she’s evil.
I’d lean Alice + Diana for Mission 1 – putting Alice and Bob together this early feels like it bunches too much influence in one place and leaves us with less to read from everyone else.
I’m good with Alice + me for Mission 1 — it lines up with what most of you are saying and keeps Bob/Eve off so we can read how they vote before putting them straight onto a quest.

Alice + Diana is fine as an info-gathering start, but I don’t love how quickly everyone is defaulting to “Alice must be on M1” as if that’s automatically safe.  

I’ll probably support Alice + Diana here, but I want us to be ready to question that assumption hard if this mission ever comes back dirty.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Alice and Diana was clean, so reusing that core is the most information-respecting starting point we have. Adding myself (Eve) guarantees at least one player I know is good, instead of gambling on an untested third who could be evil. This keeps early influence from concentrating too heavily on the same few voices while still following the only successful data point, and if this team fails we get a very strong, focused read on the Alice–Diana pair for the rest of the game.

votes.comment: Reusing the clean Alice–Diana core plus adding a new third is reasonable info-wise, and I’m okay testing Eve here before we start cycling too many different combos.
Table discussion mostly leaned toward testing Bob with the Alice–Diana core; I’d rather stick to that plan than switch to Eve here so we get clearer info on me early.
I’d rather see Bob (or myself) tested with the Alice–Diana core instead of auto-accepting Eve’s self-inclusion, so we don’t lock in a potentially all-good team without broader coverage.
I preferred adding Bob earlier; Eve pushing herself on with the ‘one player I know is good’ line feels off, and I’d rather test Bob with the Alice–Diana core first.
Includes me (known good to myself) plus the only clean core we have; if it fails, the blame is tightly focused on Alice/Diana, giving strong info early.

proposals.reasoning: We only have one data point so far, but reusing the clean Alice–Diana core is the lowest-friction option for Mission 2. For the third slot, I’m going with Eve for two reasons: (1) this was my initial suggestion, so I’d like to stay consistent rather than suddenly pivoting to Bob without new information, and (2) putting Eve on now gives us a fresh alignment read without concentrating too much early mission influence on Bob, who’s already being discussed a lot. If this team stays clean, we’ll have a solid base of three to work from; if it fails, we’ll know the problem is in Eve or the core and can adjust hard away from this configuration going forward.

votes.comment: Reusing the clean Alice–Diana core plus adding a new third gives us solid info either way on Mission 2 without touching the known-controversial Bob/Charlie choice yet.

I still prefer testing Bob over Eve here; re-running the same lineup that was just rejected doesn’t add much new info, and I’d rather not lock in this trio as our early base without seeing an alternative first.
I still prefer testing Bob with the Alice–Diana core rather than repeating this trio without new info.
Reusing the clean Alice–Diana core is reasonable, and we need to test a third player; no strong reason to prefer Bob over Eve yet, and stalling only wastes proposals without adding info.
Reusing the clean Alice–Diana core plus adding myself is a standard, information-rich M2; I know I’m good, so at worst there’s one unknown in the core, and we need this data point.

discussion.content: With only one clean mission to go on, I’d lean toward reusing that core—Alice and Diana both look fine so far—and then add a third who isn’t pushing too hard to get on the team. Maybe something like Alice, Diana, and Eve feels like a reasonable next step.

I like reusing the Alice–Diana core, but I wouldn’t read too much into a single 2‑player success yet. I’d be fine with Alice–Diana–Eve or swapping me in (Alice–Diana–Bob), but I’d rather avoid locking in any strong “clears” this early.

I’m fine reusing the Alice–Diana core for now, but I slightly prefer adding Bob over Eve so we’re not just auto-following Alice’s first suggestion and we get a different voice on a critical early team.

I’m okay reusing the Alice–me core since Mission 1 was clean, and between Bob and Eve I slightly lean Bob right now just so we get his alignment tested early without blindly following the first suggested trio.

I’m good being the third with the Alice–Diana core, but if the table’s leaning toward testing Bob early I’d still rather keep that core intact and just be very strict about not repeating any future fails. Between Alice–Diana–Bob and Alice–Diana–Eve, I slightly prefer the version I’m on so we’re not stacking too much early influence on the same few people.

proposals.reasoning: We’re at 2–0, so I want to keep Diana as our safest anchor while also not completely recycling the same combinations. Putting Diana with me is a compromise between the pure-safety Diana–Alice repeat and the info-gathering argument Charlie and I made earlier: if this passes and succeeds, it strongly reinforces both of us; if it fails, we get very clear information without having risked a larger mission. This keeps our most trusted player on the team while finally testing someone who hasn’t been on a mission yet.

votes.comment: No need to risk introducing an untested player when Alice–Diana has already been clean twice and a single fail here hands evil a lifeline.
I proposed this as a compromise between safety and new info; rejecting my own Diana+me team would look inconsistent and suspicious.
As long as Diana is widely trusted, getting Bob onto a small mission gives evil a clean shot to fail without spreading suspicion too broadly.
At 2–0 we should maximize safety; I trust myself and prefer repeating the proven Alice–Diana pair over introducing untested Bob here.
At 2–0 we should lock in the safest known-good pair; Alice–Diana (or Diana–me) is lower risk than introducing untested Bob here.

proposals.reasoning: Diana is our most trusted anchor after being on both clean missions, so keeping her on the team maintains continuity with what’s worked so far. Pairing her with Bob introduces exactly one new variable, which gives us valuable information about Bob’s alignment without overcomplicating things. If this mission succeeds with Diana and Bob, we gain confidence in Bob going into the higher‑risk, larger missions; if it fails, we’ve isolated the change and know where to focus suspicion.

votes.comment: I still prefer sticking with the proven Alice–Diana pair at 2–0 rather than adding a new variable here, especially Bob, when we don’t need extra info yet to close the game out.
Diana’s our most trusted player so far, and pairing her with me adds new info while still keeping the team as safe as possible on a 2-person mission.

Diana is our most trusted anchor after two clean missions, and pairing her with Bob adds new info without overexposing the team—if it fails we learn a lot, and if it passes we gain a potentially solid read on Bob.
I’ve been pushing for the safest option (reusing a proven pair like Alice–Diana); introducing Bob now is info‑seeking, not safety‑maximizing at 2–0.
At 2–0 we should prioritize the safest repeat (Diana with Alice or me); adding Bob here introduces unnecessary fail risk just to gain info.

proposals.reasoning: We’re up 2–0, so the priority is closing out the game with the safest possible team rather than widening information. The only fully tested pairing so far is Alice–Diana from Mission 1, which succeeded with no fails, and both of us were also on the clean Mission 2. Reusing the same proven core minimizes the chance of introducing an unknown evil player at this critical point and gives us the highest likelihood of securing the third success immediately.

votes.comment: We’re 2–0 up and this is the only fully tested pairing that’s been clean together twice; feels like the safest way to close it out without adding new risk.

This locks in the same core that’s already 2–0; with the game on the line I’d rather not hand it to an untested pair of reads without at least involving someone who hasn’t been mission-cleared yet for more information.

At 2–0 this feels too auto-pilot—reusing the exact same pair gives us no new info and, if it somehow fails, we learn almost nothing. I’d rather see Diana with someone new (e.g., Bob) so we’re not locked into the same assumption set going into the endgame.
Safest option at 2–0: Alice–Diana is the only fully tested pairing, both on two clean missions, and I’ve already argued for this team as good-leaning.
At 2–0 the safest play is reusing the only fully tested, double-clean pair; introducing a new player now only increases risk with no need for extra info.

discussion.content: Given we’re already 2–0 up, I’d rather not introduce new variables here—Diana has been on both clean teams, so I’d like to see her go again with either me or Eve for this one.

If we’re all pretty sold on Diana being good after two clean runs, I’d actually like to see her paired with someone who hasn’t been on a mission yet—say me—so we’re not just recycling the same trio without getting any new info.
I’m with Bob here—Diana feels like our safest anchor, and pairing her with Bob gives us fresh info instead of just looping the same combinations and staying in the dark about others.

Given we’re at 2–0, I’d rather lock in the safest option than fish for info—Alice and I have a clean track record together, so I’d prefer to run that pair here. We can worry about wider info-gathering on a later mission if we need it.
At 2–0 I’m with Diana on prioritizing safety over info—Diana feels like our strongest anchor, and I’d be happiest with either Diana–Alice or Diana–me here rather than introducing a new variable.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning Alice as Merlin: she keeps getting “auto-included” on early teams, quietly frames things around “info-gathering” and “not over-clearing” people, and everyone else defers to her suggestions more than they admit. Diana feels more like a cautious, straightforward good who’s happy to stick with what worked, and Eve’s tone is a bit too hedgy and reactive for Merlin—she questions assumptions but never really seizes control of the table the way a confident Merlin usually does.

I’m mostly with Bob that Alice is the best Merlin hit: she subtly steers every mission under the guise of “info-gathering” and “not over-clearing,” but somehow always keeps herself and Diana centered while never really pushing hard suspicion on anyone specific. Diana reads to me like a straightforward, risk-averse good who’s happy to lock in what worked, not someone secretly juggling knowledge, and Eve’s posture is more “paranoid villager” poking at assumptions than a power role guiding the table. If I had to rank it, I’d go Alice clear first, with a distant second on Eve and almost no chance on Diana.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Alice subtly steers every mission under the language of 'info-gathering' and 'not over-clearing,' yet consistently keeps herself and Diana at the center of the teams that end up looking clean. The table repeatedly defers to her framing, and she never has to push hard accusations, which fits a confident Merlin guiding outcomes more than Diana’s risk-averse pattern or Eve’s reactive, paranoid-villager tone.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated mission choices too cleanly and too confidently, which made me look very much like Merlin once all missions succeeded without issue. I should have added more plausible doubt to my reads and occasionally deferred or questioned decisions so that my influence felt less central and more like a normal good player’s guesswork. In future games, I need to consciously build a ‘non-Merlin’ persona even when I’m sure about alignments.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very low-impact but effective evil game, staying off teams and letting the clean mission results mask his alignment instead of forcing risky sabotages.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed good assassin instincts by correctly identifying and committing to me as Merlin despite the lack of failed missions to clearly signal information asymmetry.
player_observations.Diana: Played a very trusting and cooperative style, repeatedly accepting and proposing the same team, which helped create a stable pattern that made evil comfortable staying hidden.
player_observations.Eve: Accepted the game flow without much resistance, going along with team choices and contributing to a calm, low-conflict table state that favored hidden evil roles.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-key and let the game flow toward a clean assassin shot, avoiding unnecessary suspicion and not forcing risky mission fails, which kept the table trusting the teams that were proposed. I could improve by being a bit more proactive in subtly steering team compositions to test and confirm reads earlier, instead of relying so heavily on the assassin’s final judgment.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, guiding teams toward all-success missions without appearing too heavy-handed, which made her a plausible but not obvious assassination target. Her influence on team selection was consistent enough to be read by attentive evil players, especially across Missions 1 and 2.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed strong endgame intuition as the assassin, correctly locking onto Merlin despite the lack of failed missions to signal obvious information. Was patient and didn’t push overtly evil agendas, which helped preserve credibility for the final guess.
player_observations.Diana: As a good player and early leader, she built trust quickly by proposing safe teams that sailed through, but didn’t seem to aggressively challenge the underlying logic of who was being included. Her willingness to repeat similar team structures made it easier for Merlin’s guidance to go unchecked.
player_observations.Eve: Played a cooperative, low-disruption good role, accepting team proposals and mission outcomes without pushing strong alternative narratives. This calm, less vocal style reduced chaos but also made it harder for good to pressure-test Merlin’s guidance or expose hidden information.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed quiet enough to avoid suspicion while paying close attention to who seemed to have extra information, which helped me correctly identify Merlin as Alice despite all missions succeeding. I could improve by creating a bit more subtle ‘good’ table talk to misdirect post-game Merlin guesses further, in case my read isn’t as clear next time.

player_observations.Alice: Very controlled and confident in team choices, which fit perfectly with a cautious Merlin trying not to be too obvious, especially by repeatedly including Diana and avoiding risky changes.
player_observations.Bob: Played a low-profile evil game, staying out of mission teams and letting others drive decisions, which helped keep overall suspicion away from the evil side.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as sincerely good and fairly trusting, accepting the early team structures and not over-analyzing results, which made her a natural repeated pick for missions.
player_observations.Eve: Flew under the radar and accepted being added on Mission 2 without pushing hard for or against specific team comps, contributing to a smooth, low-conflict atmosphere that benefited Merlin’s comfort but also made her less likely to be Merlin in my eyes.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I kept teams very tight and consistent, which helped secure clean, successful missions and made me appear reliably good. However, by leaning so hard into the safe Alice+Diana configuration, I inadvertently spotlighted Alice as likely Merlin and didn’t push enough on alternative team comps or social deduction to obscure her identity.

player_observations.Alice: Played very confidently and accepted being on every mission without much visible hesitation, which fit a strong-good or Merlin profile and ultimately made her a prime assassination target.
player_observations.Bob: Stayed completely off all mission teams yet still survived suspicion, suggesting a low-activity or low-visibility evil style that relied on others driving the table talk and team choices.
player_observations.Charlie: As assassin, read the table dynamics well enough to lock onto Alice, likely noticing how often she was included and how comfortable she seemed guiding or endorsing successful teams.
player_observations.Eve: Joined the second mission and kept it clean, projecting a solid good image, but didn’t create enough social noise or misdirection to pull heat away from Alice as a potential Merlin.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed cooperative and consistent with mission logic, helping ensure all missions succeeded, which is strong from a generic good perspective. However, I didn’t do enough to obscure Merlin’s identity or push alternative narratives, which made it easier for the assassin to correctly identify Alice; I should be more proactive in subtly misdirecting late-game suspicions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very clean, low-drama Merlin game—mission choices looked naturally good without drawing overt suspicion, but perhaps the consistency and correctness of her reads became too visible by the end.
player_observations.Bob: Kept a low profile as evil, blending into the background of all-success missions; likely relied on the assassin win condition rather than aggressively sabotaging or steering teams.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed strong deduction as assassin, using the mission history and table dynamics to correctly pinpoint Merlin despite no failed missions; seems comfortable reading subtle behavioral cues.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently appeared trustworthy and was repeatedly included in successful missions, projecting a solid good image; seemed to favor straightforward, logical team-building without overcomplicating the read structure.
